Key Arguments: The consultation period for the legislation is too short and not well-publicized.
The government should not be the sole authority in policing misinformation due to its own history of spreading misinformation.
There is a need for an independent scrutinizing force to oversee the process.
Social media platforms are already influenced by governments and corporations, which could lead to further restrictions on freedom of speech.
Open public debate with balanced representation is necessary to combat misinformation effectively.
Main Themes: Lack of transparency and public engagement
Concerns about government overreach and bias
Importance of freedom of speech and open debate
Distrust in major media outlets and social media platforms
Notable Quotes: The government should not police the truthfulness of information on its own as they have shown they are responsible for the same misinformation and disinformation over the past many years.
If you are going to leave it to these social media outlets to police and be pressured by government, there will just be more freedom of speech taken away.
The only way to combat misinformation and disinformation is to have open debate about subjects publicly, with the clear and factual information presented.
